communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2024003660
communications.communication:
FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAW APPEAL

To: Town of Hempstead

Date: July 22, 2024

FOIL #  2024003660

Re: Appeal of Constructive Denial of FOIL Request

On June 24, 2024, I submitted a Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request (FOIL# 2024003660) seeking the following records:

 * A list of all Placement Partners, including their contact information (name, phone, email) and status (Active, Inactive, Terminated, Suspended).

 * Records relating to the criteria, qualifications, and documentation required for organizations to become Placement Partners.

 * Records relating to the number of animals transferred to each Placement Partner in the past year.

 * Contact information for the Director, Placement Partners Coordinator, and the Enforcement Offices.

 * Any complaints or issues that have arisen with your Placement Partners.

 * Standard Operating Procedures and related documentation for Placement Partners.

The Town acknowledged receipt of my request and indicated a response would be provided by July 22, 2024. However, no response has been received as of this date. Pursuant to FOIL, this failure to respond constitutes a constructive denial of my request, which I hereby appeal.

I respectfully request that the appropriate appeals officer render a determination on this appeal within ten (10) business days, as mandated by FOIL. If the requested records are denied in whole or in part, please provide a detailed written explanation for the denial, citing the specific statutory exemptions relied upon.

In accordance with FOIL, copies of this appeal and the Town's determination must be forwarded to:

Committee on Open Government
Department of State
One Commerce Plaza
99 Washington Ave.
Albany, New York 12231

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Jonathan Colon

Please be advised that this does not waive the Town's right to withhold records in accordance with FOIL.  All production of records is subject to redaction in accordance with FOIL.



Should you have any questions, please feel free to call me at your convenience at 516-812-3036 or via email at: marijer@hempsteadny.gov.

communications.subject: Welcome to the City of Chicago Request Center!
communications.communication:
Dear J publi, 
 
 
Thank you for registering with the City of Chicago Public Records Portal. 
If you did not submit your request through the public portal but are receiving this e-mail, we are excited to share with you that you can now submit FOIA requests through a newly implemented online request system. While you will still be allowed to email your FOIA requests, creating an account and submitting your request online will allow you to check the online portal for the status of requests. You will also receive an email when the records are ready to be downloaded.

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Emails sent to Chief Harold Scoggins from an individual using the pseudonyms "Armondo", "Armondo Castillo", and "Armondo Paredes de Castillo", along with attachments and associated emails. Note that "Armondo" may also be spelled "Armando".

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

Rose Terse

communications.subject: City of Seattle Public Records Request Center - Invoice Ready :: C192137-080424
communications.communication:
Dear Rose Terse, 
 
Records in response to your public disclosure request C192137-080424 received on August 04, 2024 are now available. The cost for the records is as follows: 
 
Invoice Number: INV24-C192137-1 
Total: $1.25 
 
To pay online, please follow these steps: 
 Please note that you will need to disable any pop-up blockers to make a payment using the system. 
 
  * Navigate to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * Select 'My Records Request Center'. 
  * Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login. 
  * Find this request: C192137-080424. 
  * Select the 'View Invoices' button. 
 
  * Opens a pop-up window showing your invoice: INV24-C192137-1. 
  * Click on the invoice and then the 'Pay Now' button. 
  * Continue processing your payment. 
  * Select 'Done'. 
  * Once the payment process is done, you are returned to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * After your payment is successful you will receive an email from our payments center. 
Once your payment has been approved, we will send you an email with instructions on how to download your records. Note that City staff must manually upload records. Records will be available one to two business days after payment. 
 
Please let your public disclosure officer (PDO) know if you are unable to pay online; your PDO will work with you on alternative ways to make your payment. 
 
You have 30 days from today's date to pay for your records. If the City does not receive your payment within this time period, your request will be considered abandoned, and you will need to submit a new request. 
 Please add seattle@mycusthelp.net to your E-mail contacts/address book to ensure delivery of the record center E-mails to your Inbox. (mailto:seattle@mycusthelp.net) 
This is an auto-generated email and has originated from an unmonitored email account. Please DO NOT REPLY.

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: Traffic Stop Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A tabular data file containing all information collected in accordance with Maryland TRANSPORTATION Code § 25-113 including but not limited to: date of stop, time of stop, race of driver, gender of driver, age of driver, if search occurred, if contraband was found, anonymized officer ID, and stop location for all years available.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Emma Parry

communications.subject: Acknowledgment MPIA 24-1453
communications.communication:
Dear Emma Parry:



This is an acknowledgement of your request below, for public information, submitted to the Document Compliance Unit ("DCU") of the Baltimore Police Department ("BPD").  Your request is governed by the Maryland Public Information Act ("PIA"), Maryland Code, General Provisions Article ("GP"), Sections 4-101 et seq.  DCU will process your request promptly.  However, our response may take longer than ten (10) working days, the reasons for which may include the scope of your request, the type and volume of potentially responsive records, and the nature of the search, review, and preparation that is required.  In any event, DCU will respond to your request within thirty (30) days. GP § 4-203.



DCU will contact you with the availability of records and the possible costs associated with this request, as soon as the information is made available by the Custodian of Records.  Likewise, if DCU and/or the Custodian of Records need you to clarify your request, DCU will contact you promptly.


Please understand that the DCU staff receive an overwhelming number of requests a month and we are working diligently to respond to each and every request as quickly as possible. We appreciate your patience; response to document requests may take longer than normal.



Please refer to tracking # MPIA 24-1453 in any subsequent correspondence pertaining to this matter.  All follow up correspondence should be made in writing and submitted to the DCU's e-mail: DCU@baltimorepolice.org<mailto:DCU@baltimorepolice.org>.
Thank you,
Sade Sesay
[cid:image001.png@01DAB7FB.FF589280]<http://www.baltimorecity.gov/>
Department of Law
Sade Sesay (she/her)

communications.communication:
Good morning Emma Parry,

Please be advised that the Document Compliance Department of the Baltimore City Police (“DCU”) is still working on gathering records to complete your request.  DCU will contact you with the availability of records and the possible costs associated with this request, as soon as the information is made available by the Custodian of Records.

Please refer to MPIA 24-1453 in any subsequent correspondence pertaining to this matter. All follow up correspondence should be made in writing and submitted to the DCU’s e-mail: DCU@baltimorepolice.org<mailto:DCU@baltimorepolice.org>.
Thank you,
Sade Sesay

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Long Beach ShotSpotter Contract
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

The most recent contract (i.e. council resolution, contract extension, contract amendments, cure notices, or other revisions to agreements) between the city and SoundThinking, Inc., formerly ShotSpotter, Inc.. This document(s) should include the total cost over the life of the contract and the current expiration date.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sophia Ludt

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #C177619-040824
communications.communication:
04-17-2024

via email to: matthew.jaeger@seattle.gov

Hello,

I sent a reply email containing questions to: LEGPDR@seattle.gov  on 04-08-2024 9 days ago, and I have received no response to my email. A copy of my email is attached. 

1. You are free to use your Granicus Corporation products (GOVQA) as you see fit, obviously. However, you are directed not to communicate with me via *any* GOVQA product. Do not send spam or any unwanted communications to me regarding this public records request via GOVQA.

2. What is the status of this public records request? 2nd request, I require an answer to my inquiry per RCW.

3. Preserve all records. Consider this email constructive notice of probable litigation regarding this public records request. If litigation is expected or anticipated in the course of processing a public records request, all responsive records are required by law to be preserved indefinitely until litigation is resolved. 

4. "fullest assistance." RCW 42.56.100 Protection of public records—Public access.

Agencies shall adopt and enforce reasonable rules and regulations, and the office of the secretary of the senate and the office of the chief clerk of the house of representatives shall adopt reasonable procedures allowing for the time, resource, and personnel constraints associated with legislative sessions, consonant with the intent of this chapter to provide full public access to public records, to protect public records from damage or disorganization, and to prevent excessive interference with other essential functions of the agency, the office of the secretary of the senate, or the office of the chief clerk of the house of representatives. Such rules and regulations shall provide for the fullest assistance to inquirers and the most timely possible action on requests for information. Nothing in this section shall relieve agencies, the office of the secretary of the senate, and the office of the chief clerk of the house of representatives from honoring requests received by mail for copies of identifiable public records.
If a public record request is made at a time when such record exists but is scheduled for destruction in the near future, the agency, the office of the secretary of the senate, or the office of the chief clerk of the house of representatives shall retain possession of the record, and may not destroy or erase the record until the request is resolved.

I am not receiving "fullest assistance" in regards to this public records request. 

Please provide answers to my questions as per law, and do not involve me with GOVQA products and/or communications.

Thank you.

communications.communication:
05-08-2024

via email to Matthew.Jaeger@seattle.gov.

Hello,

Yes, I received your emails on 04-17-24,05-01-24, 05-01-24, and 05-02-24.

I have made no "special requests" for your agency to meet:

RCW 42.56.080: Agencies shall honor requests received in person during an agency's normal office hours, or by mail or email, for identifiable public records unless exempted by provisions of this chapter. No official format is required for making a records request; however, agencies may recommend that requestors submit requests using an agency provided form or web page.

Do you have an estimate of when you may expect to produce records responsive to this request?

Thank you.

Records in response to your public disclosure request C177619-040824 received on April 01, 2024 are now available. The cost for the records is as follows:

To pay online, please follow these steps: 
 Please note that you will need to disable any pop-up blockers to make a payment using the system.

(https://u8387795.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=u001.PYICgxP3kfgZjR-2B4e9nPlIkMrj2cBe016r1is2tP0cnqKj04Rtz3gcHaKnIYvsGIcyHJj-2BtpqX9p2uRmKlqSAyxkBsAm5ymb3RyhZd0c-2Fy8-3DR-SL_qH9-2FkOHzXJFcpRqvHUkltsHjjwBXajdXmHAMwxQn0NMsOK55m19o2iN7KZxeLWk2aH18e6jnkEW-2B2yYHtcs-2FbIhscjtpnQA-2BpJo402DIahOb4nydo9rrs7y-2F1v8qFMER8FDsPUszjVH8vSnlkPAzvZMc8RZIDBH6xkpjH3w97YQsCf2srJF8U8aFKEuzD7LDujUysY6Xuw8qOhiAtkbOEU5fwhjYv4HZ5W8ZDnFICWKLe04kqQdKHLWK14EPyCONygcoggXI0jCrjyeJmGy5USchBEZCE7p8dduCXYIACB34Zn3yDNPeGPcPY1Ndby6Iy8XgVXpL0yt6lhRa2ZDSnsDlH-2BRig-2FVp5TQalj7aVtBZlZAvPGX-2FWwVPfx-2FrPIyO)

263 Huntington Ave
Boston, MA 02115

The records being made available to you at this time include the following: (INSERT A DESCRIPTION OF THE RECORDS YOU ARE PROVIDING).

Navigate to the Public Records Request Center.
Select 'My Records Request Center'.
Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login.
Select this request: C177619-040824.
Select the 'View Files' button.
You can download records individually or all at the same time by clicking 'Download All'.
Please save your records as you may only download them from the system three times.
If you do not download your records within 30 days of request closure, the link to your records will expire.
If you believe you have received privileged or confidential records in error, please notify the City of Seattle immediately, through the Public Records Request Center or by email. Privileged or confidential records provided or received in error should not be reviewed, used, disseminated, distributed, or copied, and should be destroyed immediately. Thank you in advance for your cooperation.
 
We have redacted records that are exempt from disclosure under the Public Records Act. Please see the attached exemption log.

The Public Records Act does not allow an agency to provide access to lists of individuals which have been requested for commercial purposes. RCW 42.56.070(8). Please sign and confirm the attached affidavit to confirm that you have not made this public disclosure request for commercial purposes. If we do not hear from you within 30 days regarding the affidavit, we will be unable to respond with the records that include lists of names and that part will be closed.
 
We are reviewing our request response to ensure that we have collected all responsive records. We anticipate that another installment or that we will be able to close your request by July 28, 2024. 
 
Sincerely,
Legislative Department

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Traffic Stop Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A tabular data file containing all information collected in accordance with Texas Crim. Pro. Code § 2.132-4 including but not limited to: date of stop, time of stop, race of driver, gender of driver, age of driver, if search occurred, if contraband was found, anonymized officer ID, and stop location for all years available.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Emma Parry

communications.subject: Welcome to the City of Dallas Open Records Center!
communications.communication:
Dear Emma Parry, 
Thank you for registering with the City of Dallas Open Records Center. Your Login ID is:  162443-69490224@requests.muckrock.com If you did not submit your request through the Records Center but are receiving this e-mail, an account has been created for you where you can track and monitor the status of your request, and receive any documents in response to your request. 
 If you have never used this system or cannot remember your password you may request a temporary password here: Request Temporary Password. (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=u001.aGJs94H2n3wB3Vxe3mxzET5y5yKFxs6Xf2fP3YbdNeRdF-2FWMG-2FwrlOA-2BWfh33WYhfzhV8V-2FIPE8aD92a-2Fddehg-3D-3D9pTT_3O-2BF5bDu423NpkEYSzmdzwHGhRoLia6zYH8ZHRoarBfh6Y0jQC7ZOXmysKyOpbrsJucf69Ier7Hfv7SG-2ByRAsfYlsxM8SKcaZ3sb-2BUxQNjrPOBYtXazm16rHv-2F4foAy7bFZ15xE4Yfchz764A-2BCyeFYwTtc6MlH-2BhIU84fjGNmtCv5wMfcFPo2fxq68fnOdNdcXNaZbOEhumyafZhr5rrzob-2FE7e-2BGJK3lmZTcda4Pg-3D) Please log in to the Records Center to update any contact or password information and to track the progress of your request. 
 Effective September 1, 2019, the process for requesting public records from the City of Dallas will change in response to the state’s adoption of Senate Bill 944. The Texas Legislature amended the Public Information Act to specify exactly how members of the public may submit a public information request to a governmental agency. To comply with the law, all emailed public information requests, including requests for the Dallas Police Department, must be sent to openrecords@dallascityhall.com. (mailto:openrecords@dallascityhall.com) Any requests emailed to the address associated with police records requests will be deemed not received. openrecordunit@dpd.ci.dallas.tx.us (mailto:openrecordunit@dpd.ci.dallas.tx.us) 
 
 
 
This is an auto-generated email and has originated from an unmonitored email account. Please DO NOT REPLY.

title: USACE Community Meeting Madre Vieja Channel

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: USACE Community Meeting Madre Vieja Channel
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Reports show that USACE convened a meeting with Aguada residents on May 11, 2023 about their concerns with levee placements along the Madre Vieja channel: https://periodismoinvestigativo.com/2023/07/residents-of-aguada-and-rio-piedras-require-green-alternatives-from-us-corps-of-engineers-to-channel-rivers/

Therefore, I request the following records:

1) Any digital communications, messages, emails, and attachments between your department about the aforementioned meeting with Aguada residents to discuss concerns about the levee. 

2) Any digital communications, messages, emails, and attachments between your department and persons who participated and/or helped facilitate the May 11 meeting with Aguada residents.

3) Any instructional materials, presentations, and presentation materials (including recorded video and audio, PowerPoint files, prepared remarks, and slide formats) used to prepare for or used during the May 11 meeting with Aguada residents. This includes A) any notes taken during meetings that discussed preparation for the meeting, B) notes taken during the meeting, C) any explanations (whether internally or externally generated) about the May 11 meeting, and D) any other document that has been used to help explain the proposed USACE dams along the Madre Vieja Channel (also known as the "Caño Madre Vieja").

This request is being made for all records produced between January 1, 2023 and the time this request is processed.

In the event that there are multiple responsive records, please send them to me on a rolling basis.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. I am an independent journalist and these records will be used in the course of reporting about USACE construction projects in Puerto Rico. https://muckrack.com/carlos-e-berrios-polanco

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Carlos Berríos Polanco

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: USACE Community Meeting Madre Vieja Channel
communications.communication:
Dear FOIA Officer,

I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to follow up on my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request submitted to your office on March 17, 2024. The request pertains to: digital communications about a meeting with Aguada residents that took place on May 11, 2024 about their concerns over levee placements along the Madre Vieja channel.

The request also pertained to instructional materials, presentations, and presentation materials used to prepare for or used during the May 11 meeting with Aguada residents.

As of today, July 12, 2024, I have not received any response or communication regarding the status of my request. According to the FOIA regulations (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i)), agencies are generally required to respond to FOIA requests within 20 business days from the date of receipt. It has now been well beyond that timeframe without any communication or indication of the status of my request.

Please be advised that the FOIA provides for legal remedies in cases of agency non-compliance, including the right to seek judicial review if an agency fails to respond to a FOIA request within the statutory time frame. While I hope to resolve this matter amicably and swiftly, I must insist on prompt action to fulfill my request or provide a specific explanation for any delay.

Therefore, I kindly request an immediate update on the status of my request and an estimated timeline for when I can expect to receive the responsive records. If there are any issues or additional information needed to process my request, please do not hesitate to contact me at 787-449-4731 or carlosBP@protonmail.com.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response.

Sincerely,
Carlos Berríos Polanco

title: Legislative Assembly Fair Work Week emails

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Legislative Assembly Fair Work Week emails
communications.communication:
Date: July 5, 2024

To:

Legislative Branch Public Records Request
c/o Office of the Legislative Counsel
900 Court Street NE S101
Salem, Oregon 97301-4065
Email: Leg.RecReq@oregonlegislature.gov

From:

Peter Fugiel
Postdoctoral Research Fellow
Rutgers School of Management and Labor Relations

Dear Public Records Staff,

I am writing to request public records from the Oregon Legislative Assembly for academic research on scheduling legislation. Specifically, I am requesting:

Emails sent or received between January 1, 2016, and December 31, 2017, by any Legislator or their staff containing the phrase "fair work week" in the message text or attachments, excluding internal advisory communications. I request that the responsive records be provided in electronic format. 

I request a fee waiver because my research is in the public interest as judged by the National Science Foundation (award # 2203815). But if there are any fees associated with fulfilling this request, please provide an estimate of these costs before proceeding. If my request is unclear or too broad, I would appreciate your assistance in narrowing the scope.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your response as soon as practicable or within five business days.

Sincerely,

Peter Fugiel
Postdoctoral Research Fellow
Rutgers School of Management and Labor Relations
c/o MuckRock News
411A Highland Ave
Somerville, MA 02144-2516
peter.fugiel@rutgers.edu
260-468-8528

communications.subject: Fwd: Public Records Request PRR 732
communications.communication:
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Leg RecReq <Leg.RecReq@oregonlegislature.gov>
Date: Tue, Jul 9, 2024 at 10:27 AM
Subject: Public Records Request PRR 732
To: peter.fugiel@rutgers.edu <peter.fugiel@rutgers.edu>


Good morning Peter,



Attached please find an acknowledgment letter regarding your recent public
records request.



Before we begin the process of collecting any records potentially
responsive to your request, I’d like to share some information with you
about fees associated with records requests received by Oregon’s
Legislative Branch, and to that end, I have attached our fee policy. In
short, though: your request, as is, may qualify for a 40% fee reduction,
but it does not qualify for a fee waiver. To qualify for a fee waiver, the
request, among other things, must be narrowly tailored to preserve public
resources, which it is not as it seeks records from a two year period from
roughly 90 offices. Speaking more frankly, I can also tell you that a
search in our e-mail records collection tool of “fair work week”
unfortunately won’t only return hits with “fair work week” -- it will
return anything with “fair,” “work,” or “week” in it, which I’m sure you
can imagine will create countless (likely many thousands of) records that
are not responsive to your request and that will need to be sorted through
before we can provide you with the records that are responsive.



If you would like to read through the attached policy and can confirm that
your request meets all of the qualifications for a fee reduction, I can
proceed with the request as is and will grant you the 40% fee reduction,
but would ask for your patience as this request will take months of work to
complete. I am also happy to work with you to help you reconfigure your
request to be more specific (for example, by narrowing the search window,
or seeking records from fewer offices) so that we can grant that full fee
waiver. If we do proceed with a fee reduction only, I will make sure to
communicate a fee estimate before we actually begin processing your request.



Please let me know how you would like to proceed once you’ve had a chance
to read through the attached policy document.



Best,



*Michael Burns *|* Legal and Public Records Assistant*

Office of the Legislative Counsel

Office: 503.986.1243

[image: http://intranet/CapitolImages/Oregon%20State%20Seal%20-%20Color.jpg]

files.title: prr732 acknowledgment
files.source: Oregon Legislative Assembly, Oregon

communications.subject: Re: Public Records Request PRR 732
communications.communication:
Dear Michael,

Thank you for acknowledging my request and sharing the fee reduction/waiver
policy. I understand the need to weigh the public interest in the records
requested against the burden of retrieving and reviewing them. I would be
happy to narrow my request by limiting the number of email accounts and
period of time.

Before I revise my request, I wonder if you could clarify how these records
(legislative email messages and attachments) are stored and searched for
the purposes of public records requests. I am surprised to learn that your
collection tool does not allow for compound search terms or operators (e.g.
fair AND work AND week). One way of working around this limitation might be
to narrow the keyword search to certain fields, e.g. the email subject or
attachment file name. Another possibility would be to search for records
containing relevant bill numbers (SB878, SB888) instead of common words.
But I'm not sure if you can search specific fields or metadata of these
emails. I would appreciate any further information or assistance you could
provide in tailoring my request.

All the best,
Peter

files.title: image001
files.source: Oregon Legislative Assembly, Oregon

communications.subject: RE: Public Records Request PRR 732
communications.communication:
Hi Peter,

I’m glad you asked, because it gave me an opportunity to check in with the team that pulls e-mails for us (our IT folks are the ones who pull the records, while we review, redact, and discuss/disseminate them with/to the various concerned parties.) What they told me is that compound search terms with operators do (read: should) work, and that if I am seeing results that contradict that we can investigate why. Since I frequently see evidence to the contrary, I’ll have an opportunity to review with them the next time the issue comes up. It’s quite possible that user error (i.e. using operators in lower case instead of all caps) yielded nonresponsive records in the past. Thankfully we do always find the correct records (assuming they exist)... we just tend to end up with a lot of separating the wheat from the chaff, which isn’t practical for obvious reasons.

The tool they use, by the way, is Office 365 eDiscovery. It doesn’t allow you to limit what fields you’re searching in, but if you’re curious, this<https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/ediscovery-keyword-queries-and-search-conditions?view=o365-worldwide> article discusses the ins-and-outs of how to use it.

As for your current request: really, I can limit it however you’d like. The goal here is to make sure you are getting the records you want and are entitled to, so I’d like to make sure we’re doing it right. I’ll just need you to specify the conditions so I’m not misinterpreting anything. We can use your original search terms, and can also add SB###, SB ###, Senate Bill ###, etc. to the list of terms. The search will find hits in both e-mails and attachments. The biggest issue remains the number of accounts you’re asking us to pull records from, and the best advice I can offer is to limit your search to members of the Legislative Assembly and committees that actually worked on whichever bills you’re interested in. You’ll need to do the research on that if that’s a route you’d like to take, but OLIS<https://www.oregonlegislature.gov/bills_laws/Pages/previous-session-bills.aspx> is a great place to start.

I’ll await further correspondence. Have a great day in the meantime.

Michael

files.title: image001
files.source: Oregon Legislative Assembly, Oregon

communications.subject: RE: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Legislative Assembly Fair Work Week emails
communications.communication:
Good morning Michael,

I appreciate you checking with your IT colleagues and clarifying the functionality of the Office 365 eDiscovery tool. I would like to narrow my request for emails and attachments to the period 1/1/2017–12/31/2017 and the following eight members of the Legislative Assembly: Senate President Peter Courtney, Senator Michael Dembrow, Senator Tim Knopp, Senator Alan DeBoer, Senator Ted Ferrioli, House Speaker Tina Kotek, Representative Kathleen Taylor, or Representative Greg Barreto. I would like to add the bill number (828) as an alternate search term. Putting these modifications together, here is my revised request:

Emails sent or received between January 1, 2017 and December 31, 2017 by Greg Barreto, Peter Courtney, Alan DeBoer, Michael Dembrow, Ted Ferrioli, Tina Kotek, Tim Knopp, or Kathleen Taylor that contain the compound phrase "fair AND work AND week" OR the number 828 in the message text or attachments, excluding internal advisory communications.

Please note that I am most interested in records that deal with the provisions, amendments, testimony, deliberations, or votes on this measure. If my search returns records that merely list the bill with its sponsors, status, or other summary information, you may exclude these records from your review and response.

Thank you for your assistance,
Peter

communications.subject: RE: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Legislative Assembly Fair Work Week emails
communications.communication:
Peter, thank you. I will put in a request for the records and will get back to you when I have an update.

Micnael

communications.subject: RE: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Legislative Assembly Fair Work Week emails

To Whom It May Concern:

communications.subject: RE: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Legislative Assembly Fair Work Week emails
communications.communication:
Good morning Peter,

Thanks for checking in and for your patience.

For your request, there are ~1,000 potentially responsive records. I completed an initial review on those yesterday and am preparing to distribute them to target offices who will need to review them for any potential redactions or exemptions before we send them out to you. I expect to send them to the target offices this Friday, with a one-week timeframe for their review. Once that’s done, I’ll need to apply any applicable redactions. At this point I expect to have records ready to deliver to you by Monday, August 12th. If for whatever reason we can’t make that deadline, I will update you with a new ETA.
Best,

Michael

communications.subject: RE: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Legislative Assembly Fair Work Week emails
communications.communication:
Good morning Michael,

Thank you for the update. I look forward to receiving the records once your colleagues have reviewed them and you apply any applicable redactions.

All the best,
Peter

communications.subject: Public Records Request PRR 732
communications.communication:
Peter,

Attached please find a disclosure letter regarding your public records request, as well as DropBox links to all responsive records for which an exemption was not claimed. Please note that a few of the legislators you specified (Alan DeBoer, Ted Ferrioli, and Greg Barreto) have been retired from the Legislative Assembly long enough that the retention period on their records has expired, and thus we haven't provided those as we simply don't have them anymore.

Best of luck on your research, and apologies for the number of records in here that actually don't tell the story of the evolution of the laws you are interested in (i.e. newsletters mentioning "fair work week" legislation)--separating those out would actually have taken considerably more time, making it harder to justify the full fee waiver. That said, I hope you'll find what you are looking for here.

This completes our response to your request.

Records:

Rep Tina Kotek1<https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/80ko4qt3v4ci30w6t72md/prr732-records-Rep.TinaKotek.pdf?rlkey=jz6svfio4xc9g1xktu4bpg1nw&st=qscj1iz4&dl=0>

title: Sheriff data collection request 2022 (Thurston County Sheriff)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Sheriff data collection request 2022 (Thurston County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. the total number of use of force incidents in 2022. Please include as part of this a breakdown of how many use of force incidents in 2022 were related to law enforcement operations and how many were related to correctional/custodial operations. 
2. the total number of use of force incidents, separated by type of force, in 2022 (for example, information that specifies the number of taser incidents in 2022, baton incidents in 2022, etc.)
 3. the total number of civilian complaints against law enforcement that were reported and the total number sustained for 2022. 
4. the total number of civilian complaints alleging law enforcement use of excessive force that were reported and the total number sustained for 2022. 
5. the total number of civilian complaints alleging biased policing or racial profiling that were reported and the total number sustained for 2022. 
6. the total number of civilian complaints alleging criminal conduct that were reported and the total number sustained for 2022.
 7. the total number of officer-involved shootings in 2022, both fatal and non-fatal. 
8. the total number of people who the sheriff’s department used force against, broken down by race/ethnicity, in 2022.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

We have begun a process to search for records responsive to your request. We reasonably believe that at least a first installment of public records (if any) responsive to this request (specifically #3, #4, #5, #6, and #7) will be available on or before January 18, 2024. In order to ensure we are responding to #1, #2, and #8 accurately; I have outlined some questions and comments in a copy of your requests below.  Please take note of the information in red and respond by January 4, 2024 if you would like me to proceed searching for responsive records to #1, #2, and #8: 
1. the total number of use of force incidents in 2022. Please include as part of this a breakdown of how many use of force incidents in 2022 were related to law enforcement operations and how many were related to correctional/custodial operations. We do not list Use of Force by number. I can provide each Use of Force report and you would need to determine which is related to Corrections and which is related to Patrol***. 
2. the total number of use of force incidents, separated by type of force, in 2022 (for example, information that specifies the number of taser incidents in 2022, baton incidents in 2022, etc.) We do not list Use of Force by type. I can provide each Use of Force report and you would need to determine the type of force***. 
3. the total number of civilian complaints against law enforcement that were reported and the total number sustained for 2022. 
4. the total number of civilian complaints alleging law enforcement use of excessive force that were reported and the total number sustained for 2022. 
5. the total number of civilian complaints alleging biased policing or racial profiling that were reported and the total number sustained for 2022. 
6. the total number of civilian complaints alleging criminal conduct that were reported and the total number sustained for 2022. 
7. the total number of officer-involved shootings in 2022, both fatal and non-fatal. 
8. the total number of people who the sheriff’s department used force against, broken down by race/ethnicity, in 2022. We do not list Use of Force by race/ethnicity. I can provide each Use of Force report and you would need to determine race/ethnicity***. ***Please note, there will be hundreds of reports that will each require 3rd party notification, redaction and payment when available. I will move forward with #1, #2 and #8 until I have heard from you that you NOT want me to begin searching for these reports. DO 
Our agency wants to ensure that we are providing exactly the records you want, so our attempt to clarify your request is aimed at meeting that objective. With clear direction, we can focus our search efforts in a more efficient manner. 

Please note that, absent further clarification from you, we will begin to process the request as we currently understand it. 
If public records become available in advance of this estimate, we will contact you promptly. Conversely, if the County encounters a need to extend our estimate, we will contact you with a revised estimated date. 
If you have any questions, you may contact me at 360-596-5155. 

Sincerely, 

Jennifer Matheson 
Legal Assistant 
TCSO-PDR Section

January 02, 2024 

Samuel Sinyangwe 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR154728 263 Huntington Ave 
Boston MA 02115 

Dear Samuel Sinyangwe: 

This communication is regarding your public records request, #S026364-112123. 

The first installment of records responsive to your request is now available for purchase. An invoice is available to you on this request through the Public Records Center. 
You may submit your payment online through the Public Records Center by using a credit card. Please note that a credit card processing fee of $2.00 or 2.35%, whichever is greater, will apply.  
Alternatively, you may mail a money order payable to the Thurston County Sheriff's Office, ATTN: Accounting, 2000 Lakeridge Dr. SW, Bldg. 3, Olympia, WA 98502. Please include a copy of your invoice or your request number with your payment. 
You may also submit a cash payment (exact amount only) in person at the Sheriff's Office, 2000 Lakeridge Dr. SW, Olympia, WA 98502 during the normal business hours of 8:30 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday (excluding legal holidays). The office is located in Building 3 of the courthouse complex. Please bring a copy of your invoice with you if you are submitting payment in person. 
Once payment has been received, responsive records will be processed for release during normal business hours of the assigned staff, andnotice will be sent when they are accessible. 
This request will be closed if payment has not been received by February 01, 2024. 
Provided we hear from you by February 01, 2024, we reasonably believe that a second installment of public records (if any) responsive to this request will be available on or before February 15, 2024. If public records become available in advance of this estimate we will contact you promptly. Conversely, if the County encounters a need to extend our estimate, we will contact you with a revised estimated date. We will communicate with you and keep you informed of any updates regarding collecting and obtaining the responsive records as we move through the process. 

We have made no redactions to this installment of responsive records. 

If you have any questions, you may contact me at 360-596-5155. 

Sincerely,

TCSO-PDR Section

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #S026364-112123
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I'm following up on the following Washington Public Records Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on Nov. 21, 2023. You had previously indicated that it would be completed on Feb. 15, 2024. I wanted to check on the status of my request, and to see if there was a new estimated completion date.  You had assigned it reference number #S026364-112123.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: [Records Center] Sheriff's Office Records Request :: S026364-112123
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

February 21, 2024 

Samuel Sinyangwe 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR154728 263 Huntington Ave 
Boston MA 02115 

Dear Samuel Sinyangwe: 

This communication is regarding your public records request, #S026364-112123. 
The second installment of records responsive to your request is available for review and download via your account on the Public Records Center. 
If you experience any difficulty viewing the records, please disable any pop-up blockers on your internet browser, as these may block your access to the records. 
Please note that some information has been redacted from the records produced to you pursuant to the Public Records Act. The exemption letter and key which is also being provided to you via your account on the Public Records Center will explain how the redactions are made, and the statutory basis for the redactions. 
We reasonably believe that a third installment of public records responsive to this request will be available on or before April 11, 2024. If public records become available in advance of this estimate we will contact you promptly. Conversely, if the County encounters a need to extend our estimate, we will contact you with a revised estimated date. We will communicate with you and keep you informed of any updates regarding collecting and obtaining the responsive records as we move through the process. 

If you have any questions, you may contact me at 360-596-5155. 

Sincerely, 

Jennifer Matheson 
Legal Assistant 
TCSO-PDR Section
